Explanation: ｛で/から｝できる　means "to be made of/from/out of." から indicates that the material(s) from which something is made is not immediately obvious. できる is used in generic statements while できている is used when describing something specific
English: ～でできる= be made of; be made out of  ～からできる = be made from
SentenceJapanese: チーズやヨーグルトは牛乳からできます
SentenceCloze: チーズやヨーグルトは{}
SentenceEnglish: Cheese and yoghurt are made from milk

Explanation: ように is used when (1) X resembles Y, (2) when X is as Y shows, says, explains, etc., or (3) when X does something as shown.said/explained/etc. in/by Y
SentenceJapanese: これはチョコレートのように見えるけれど、消しゴムだから、食べられませんよ。

ClozeAnswer: チョコレートのように

Explanation: The masu stem of a verb and the stem of an i-adjective + く indicate that the sentence is continuing.  THat is, they function like the English sentence connect "and." This use is generally restricted to written language. In spoken language the te-form of a verb or an i-adjective is commonly used.
SentenceJapanese: 昨日は友達とレストランで晩御飯を食べ、その後、映画を見に行った
SentenceCloze: 昨日は友達とレストランで晩御飯を{}、その後、映画を見に行った
SentenceEnglish: I had dinner at a restaurant with my friend yesterday and then went and saw a movie.

Explanation: The masu stem of a verb and the stem of an i-adjective + く indicate that the sentence is continuing.  THat is, they function like the English sentence connect "and." Point: Verb-non-past こと{が/も} ある
Explanation: V-plain.non-past ことがある is used when something occurs (or someone does something) occasionally.  も implies that something else may also occur. Note: This phrase should not be confused with the prase V-plain.past ことがある (e.g. 日本に行ったことがある), which has a different meaning
SentenceJapanese: 晩御飯はたいてい家で食べますが、時々友達とレストランに行くこともあります
SentenceCloze: 晩御飯はたいてい家で食べますが、時々友達とレストランに{}
SentenceEnglish: I normally eat dinner at home, but sometimes I go to a restaurant with my friends

Point: {Noun1/Question-word ~か/~かどうか}はNoun2に{よって違う/よる}
Explanation: This structure is used to indicate that something differs depending on the situation, location, time, etc.

Explanation: In some situations, A in AのB is a noun with a particle such as へ、で、と、から、and まで. が、を、and に never occur in this position.  Note that の cannot be omitted in this case because it indicates that the preceding noun phrase and particle modifies the following noun phrase.  Without の, the noun phrase with the particle is interpreted as an adverbial phrase modifying the predicate in the clause.
SentenceJapanese: 友達へのプレゼント
SentenceCloze: 友達{}プレゼント
SentenceEnglish: A present for a friend

Explanation: In some situations, A in AのB is a noun with a particle such as へ、で、と、から、and まで. が、を、and に never occur in this position. Withoutt の, the noun phrase with the particle is interpreted as an adverbial phrase modifying the predicate in the clause.

Point: ～は Sentence と言われている (NECKTIE)
Explanation: This structure is used to introduce something commonly said about something or someone.
English: ~ is said to be ~; It is said that ~

Hint: is said to be the nile

ClozeAnswer: はナイルかわだと言われている
SentenceEnglish: Some people say that the longest river in the world is Nile, but others say it is the Amazon River

Explanation: ～と言えば, which literally means "if you say that ~," is used to present, as the topic, something or someone that has just been mentioned by the hearer or the speaker.
SentenceJapanese: A: これは昔話の絵本ですね。B:そうですね。あ、昔話と言えば、木の　「桃太郎」の紙芝居を見ましたよ。
SentenceCloze: A: これは昔話の絵本ですね。B:そうですね。あ、{}、木の　「桃太郎」の紙芝居を見ましたよ。
SentenceEnglish: A: This is an old story book. B: That's right. Oh, speaking of old stories, I saw the picture-story show of the tree "Momotaro".

Explanation: ～と言えば, which literally means "if you say that ~," is used to present, as the topic, something or someone that has just been mentioned by the hearer or the speaker.
SentenceJapanese: A: 今晩、道子さんに会うんです。B: そうですか。道子さんと言えば、来月田中さんと結婚すると聞きましたが、本当ですか。
SentenceCloze: A: 今晩、道子さんに会うんです。B: そうですか。{}、来月田中さんと結婚すると聞きましたが、本当ですか。
SentenceEnglish: A: I will see Mr. Michiko this evening. B: I see. Speaking of Mr. Michiko, I heard that he will marry Mrs. Tanaka next month, is it true?

Explanation: ～と言えば, which literally means "if you say that ~," is used to present, as the topic, something or someone that has just been mentioned by the hearer or the speaker.
SentenceJapanese: A: 私の両親は、今香港に住んでいるんです。B: いいですね。香港と言えば、山の上から見る夜の景色がすばらしいそうですね。
